awd_titl_txt: The STEM Ambassadors Program: Building An Inclusive Community of Scholars through Mentoring and Research
awd_abstract_narration:
To maintain global competitiveness and a high standard of living for its citizens, the nation requires a strong scientific and technical workforce.  Evidence is mounting on the importance of student participation in a ecosystem of activities designed to support success in academic programs in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).  An important element is participation in authentic undergraduate research experiences, that in its traditional form is a resource-intensive activity.  The STEM Ambassadors Program at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and its partner institutions (Holyoke Community College and University of Massachusetts, Boston) will develop and test a scalable low-cost model for offering authentic research experiences to STEM students using Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences (CUREs) as a component of a network of activities for student success.  The research team will investigate academic success using a Social Cognitive Career Theory framework to identify and examine cognitive, contextual, and cultural variables that impact student trajectories in their academic programs.  The multi-site longitudinal mixed methods comparative study tests the hypothesis that student success, retention, and graduation in STEM are affected by institutional context, student formal course load, engagement in research, participation in a network of formal and informal mentors and advisors, volunteering in a variety of STEM outreach activities, and participation in a rich offering of STEM-related social events. 

With regards to intellectual merit, The Social Cognitive Career Theory (SCCT) framework suggests that career interests are shaped by socio-cognitive and behavioral inputs over time and are influenced by environmental supports and barriers.  The multi-site sequential-explanatory study will utilize a qualitative wave of data collection to explain and inform the Hierarchical Linear Modeling of individual growth over time.   Quantitative data include repeated measures of key SCCT constructs, such as STEM self-efficacy STEM outcome expectations, and STEM interest and goals. Control groups are sampled from the population of students that were eligible and invited to STEM AP, but did not join.  Regarding broader impacts, findings from the research will contribute to a growing body of literature on increasing student success for a diverse population of students pursuing degrees in STEM.

por.por_cntn:
It is vitally important to educate and prepare a highly qualified and diverse STEM workforce.  Diversity drives innovation and a lack of it results in our inability to harness the full potential of our STEM workforce. A dissappointing fact is that only half of college students majoring in STEM fields will graduate and pursue a career in STEM, and even fewer will be underrepresented minorities. For some, it is the cold, sterile environment in many STEM classrooms that turns them away; others don?t see themselves in most STEM professions and their instructors, often white males, reinforce this observed lack of diversity; and for still others, they are told early on that they don?t have ?what it takes? to make it in STEM fields.  

 We have engaged in a 7 year journey to create and assess "STEM Ambassadors", a retention program designed to provide a supportive, inclusive community that welcomes and embraces the diversity of our STEM college students.  STEM Ambassadors provides key educational support, professional skills development, and culturally aware activities.  It is a community our students have embraced and over which they have taken ownership.  The program provides robust and multi-faceted support with mentoring and community building woven throughout. The STEM Ambassadors Program or simply ?STEM,? as our students have named it, focuses on building students? science identity, strengthening their leadership skills, providing rich research experiences, and nurturing their overall sense of self-efficacy.   

We believe what we created is a viable pathway to retaining underrepresented students in STEM.  Much of our prior STEM retention efforts focused single-mindedly on defining, developing, and refining specific retention practices, ensuring students have access to them, and tracking the student outcomes.  With this intense focus on the mechanics of our approaches, many of us have forgotten something even more basic that our students need from us.  They need us to listen, to take the time to hear what they have to say and to respond directly to those concerns and desires.  Yes, our students want research experiences and benefit immensely from mentoring.  However, what has gotten lost in this race to retain ? is the simple fact that our students first, and foremost, need to be heard.

In the process of creating STEM AP, we learned that listening to our students was the key to building a successful STEM retention program.  Further, we believe that this may be the single most important thing one can do to ensure that the greatest diversity of students succeed in their STEM studies. We encourage everyone to make a conscious effort to listen more closely to their students, and invite them to share what they need to feel part of the diverse, productive and engaging classroom, community of scholars or workforce that you hope to achieve.

In the case of STEM AP, the students have taken ownership of the program and transformed it into a student-run club focused on STEM retention. We are delighted with this outcome as it speaks directly to the fact that the students want this support structure and are willing to do the hard work to keep it going. In addition, the PI of this grant, in concert with the program director and a former STEM Ambassador student are publishing a book that describes the history of this program, the ingredients and recipes that resulted in the success of our program, and provides some insights into how one can create a version of the program that will work in their own college or university. Even more important, the book is rich with the voices of former STEM AP participants. We engage the reader in listening to our students as they relate their experiences as STEM students and how STEM AP helped them achieve their academic goals.
